Special protections for children and simple controls for everyday users provide common ground between privacy advocates, businesses, and regulators while preserving room for responsible technological progress.
statements.201: User data should be stewarded with the care of a well-tended garden: collect only what is necessary, protect it with strong, transparent security, and provide plain-language controls, meaningful consent, and timely remedies when misuse occurs. Practical, enforceable standards—privacy-by-design, data minimization, portability, and independent audits—can sustain innovation while safeguarding individual dignity and public safety, building durable trust between users, businesses, and regulators.
statements.769: Data stewardship should be practical and reliable like maintaining well‑built machinery: collect only what is necessary, secure it to strong standards, and keep auditable records so people can understand and control how their information is used. A balanced framework—plain‑language consent, easy portability and deletion, independent audits, and proportionate oversight—lets innovation thrive while protecting privacy, offering accessible remedies for misuse and safeguarding vulnerable communities.
statements.52: User data should be treated as a form of trust, protected with strong security, strict minimization, and plain‑language choices so people can control how information affects their wellbeing. Meaningful consent, easy controls, independent audits, and timely remedies—paired with proportionate regulation that preserves useful innovation—can bridge privacy advocates and businesses while safeguarding children and vulnerable users.
statements.91: Tech companies must act as disciplined stewards of user data by minimizing collection, securing information to rigorous standards, and offering clear, plain‑language controls and consent so individuals can make informed choices. Practical, enforceable measures—independent audits, timely breach notification, data portability, and narrowly tailored lawful access—will balance innovation and public‑safety needs while providing accountability and remedies when harms occur.
statements.236: User data ought to be stewarded like any trusted asset: collected only as necessary, secured to high technical standards, and explained in plain language so people can make informed choices. Practical, enforceable measures—meaningful consent and opt‑in defaults, data minimization, portability, independent audits, prompt breach notification, and accessible remedies—can protect privacy without needlessly stifling useful innovation or legitimate public‑safety needs. Sensible regulation and industry standards should align incentives so companies build trustworthy products, preserve consumer dignity, and maintain the freedom to develop technologies that benefit communities.
statements.464: User data should be treated like a trusted household possession: collect only what is truly necessary, secure it vigorously, explain uses in plain language, and give people straightforward choices and clear remedies when trust is broken. Practical, proportionate oversight—through independent audits and enforceable rules—can balance privacy with legitimate innovation and public safety so communities can rely on technology without sacrificing dignity or common-sense protections.
statements.139: Tech companies must steward personal data as a public trust—collect only what is necessary, secure it with strong, up‑to‑date protections, and explain uses and choices in clear, plain language so people and families can make informed decisions. Enforceable standards, independent audits, easy controls including portability and deletion, and fair remedies for misuse will balance innovation with privacy, allowing useful services to flourish while protecting vulnerable users and public safety.
statements.37: User data should be managed as a matter of practical stewardship: collect only what is necessary, secure it to high technical standards, and explain uses in plain, straightforward terms so families and individuals can make informed choices. Reasonable, enforceable rules—meaningful consent defaults, independent audits, data portability, and timely remedies for misuse—can protect privacy without needlessly stifling innovation or useful services. Bridging common-sense regulation with industry best practices will restore trust, protect the vulnerable, and allow technology to continue delivering benefits to communities and businesses alike.
statements.206: Responsible stewardship of user data demands minimizing collection, safeguarding information with rigorous security, and offering plain‑language controls and meaningful consent so people can make informed choices while businesses continue to innovate. Reasonable, enforceable oversight—independent audits, data portability, timely remedies for misuse, and narrowly tailored legal access for bona fide emergency or public‑safety needs—creates common ground between privacy advocates and industry while protecting both individual rights and community safety.
statements.659: User data should be treated as entrusted information, managed with ethical stewardship that emphasizes data minimization, strong security, and plain‑language consent so people can make informed, dignified choices. Practical, proportionate measures—independent oversight, affordable compliance for smaller organizations, clear remedies for harm, and room for responsible innovation—can protect vulnerable communities and restore public trust without needlessly stifling useful services.
statements.563: Years spent helping people navigate services show trust grows from clear, plain-language explanations, simple control choices, and reliable safeguards that protect the most vulnerable. Tech companies should therefore treat data as an entrusted resource—collect only what is necessary, secure it robustly, offer easy consent and portability, submit to independent audits, and provide prompt remedies—so innovation can continue while everyday people retain dignity, safety, and usable control. Reasonable, enforceable standards shaped with public input and attention to accessibility will bridge privacy and public-safety concerns without shutting down useful services.
statements.304: Tech companies must practice disciplined stewardship of user data—collecting only what is necessary, securing it rigorously, and offering clear, plain‑language and visual explanations and controls so people can make informed decisions. Practical accountability—independent audits, meaningful remedies, data portability, and privacy‑by‑design—can balance innovation with public safety and social benefit. Special protections for children and vulnerable communities, paired with proportionate, collaborative regulation developed with diverse stakeholders, will build trust while allowing useful services to flourish.
statements.567: User data should be stewarded with the same rigor and transparency expected of trusted investigations: collect only what is necessary, secure and document use carefully, and explain practices in plain language so individuals retain meaningful control. Independent audits, enforceable rights like portability and timely remediation, and narrowly tailored lawful‑access procedures can balance innovation and public safety while protecting vulnerable people and restoring public trust.
statements.312: User data should be treated like household valuables: collect only what is necessary, secure it with strong, proven protections, and explain uses in plain language so families and children can make informed choices. Practical, enforceable measures—simple opt‑in defaults, easy-to-use controls and data portability, independent audits, and prompt breach notification—give people real control without burying consent in legalese. Reasonable, proportionate regulation that focuses on accountability and clear standards can protect privacy while allowing honest innovation and fair competition.
statements.320: Responsible stewardship of user data should prioritize protecting families, vulnerable people, and personal dignity while enabling beneficial innovation. That stewardship includes minimizing collection, securing information to rigorous standards, offering plain‑language consent and control with data portability and timely remedies, and submitting practices to independent oversight and proportionate regulation so trust and public utility are sustained.
statements.114: Tech companies should steward user data like a shared canvas—collect only what is necessary, secure it with strong protections, and explain uses in plain language so families and creators can trust digital spaces. Meaningful consent, simple controls, independent audits, and timely remedies protect the vulnerable while allowing responsible innovation and lawful public-safety uses. Sensible, enforceable regulation grounded in privacy-by-design and data portability balances business viability with social justice, keeping technology accountable to the people it serves.
